choices: It's a SUPER review, praising your story to the skies.
It's a constructive review, giving several helpful suggestions.
It's a very short review, with an offer to go in to more detail.
The reviewer says the story reminds her / him of something
the reviewer dislikes your story for many reasons
1.content:
You've got the best idea ever for a story.

It is just bubbling inside you, waiting to be written. You can't help it. It doesn't matter that your boss will be upset, the meeting can wait, the client can wait. You're going to stay home and write up your story. It's worth it to go late to work, to write up your brilliant story.

You sit at your keyboard and tap the story out. The writing just flows. Five cups of coffee and four irate messages from your boss later, you're done with your story.

It's a masterpiece.

It's the best thing you've ever written.

You're going to enter it in every contest there is, and by golly, you're going to win!

To start with, you link it on all the 'please review' pages you can find.

Then, you go to office. (The meeting goes well and your boss is happy, so that's out of the way! )

On your return from office, you check your inbox.

Your story has a review!
1.title: Writing and Receiving a Review

choices: The two of them go to a self publisher to collaborate their work
Lissa Says she wants to do her own book
you decide which way to go.
They decide to bring their collaborations to be reviewed at WDC
The two of them become smitten with each other
11.content:
You are so excited by the review, it is one of the best you have ever received. The reviewer tells you that your story is so very inventive and original, a very creative piece to be sure. You are so happy, it brings tears to your eyes. You receive five stars and are told there is not any corrections that need be made.

You decide you will start entering it in more contests, trying to win a quills award for the year of writing this piece. Your reviewer tells you that you should probably win one with the excellent work you have done. The reviewer says he would like to meet you to see what kind of person can write something so free from errors and what he believes will be a prize winning item.

The two of you live in the same town, so you decide to meet for coffee at the mall, where you can discuss, a possible collaboration on a book.
The two of you have similar work, which can be combined to create a creative piece of work. You read over some of the poetry that your reviewer, Bob, has brought with him. While he reads over other items of yours...

"Lissa", he says.
"You have a very unique way of writing and I think if we combine our work together into one book I think we will have a masterpiece."
11.title: It's a SUPER review, praising your story to...

choices: You send a polite reply saying thank you and start doing somehting else
You send a reply saying thank you and try to strike up a conversation
You tell Darkmouse to stop stalking you
You suddenly hear a loud knock at your door
12.content:
I sat down in front of my laptop with my writing.com inbox displayed before me. There were a couple of notifications of newsfeed post replies, an E-mail informing me that someone had purchased me some raffle tickets and a reply from a friend to an E-mail I had sent her a few days ago asking how her daughters wedding had gone, and then, right at the top - so most recently sent, a review.

It was a review to the story I had posted earlier that day, which I had uncharacteristically subsequently posted on the "Please Review" page with a flourish. I wondered now whether that had been a good idea. The confidence which had oozed from my fingers as I typed that morning had dissipated somewhat, as the day started to fade in to evening and the reality of my abilities as a short story writer had sunk in. Poetry was my forte, after all. My short stories were rarely appreciated with gusto and were usually picked apart for a zillion tiny grammar mistakes.

Warily, I opened the E-mail, visibly balking at the content before I had even started reading it - the review was practically an essay in itself - how anyone had thought of this amount to say about my 1500 word story was anyone's guess. With that much energy they could surely have written their own short story. I scrolled down to the bottom, curious of the rating - and expecting something dreadful, but they had given four stars. Four stars? That was reasonable. I scrolled back up and started reading the review properly. The reviewer was called DARKMOUSE9, and had been a member for a year, although I couldn't remember coming across him or her before. DARKMOUSE - it would appear, really liked the way I told a story, as well as my plot, yet unsurprisingly found holes in my grammar and listed them at great length as well as finding my main character a little unbelievable.

I clicked on Darkmouse's suitcase to access their port, which gave me little information about my reviewer. The profile picture displayed was a photograph - probably pinched from the internet- of a white mouse in shadow (very clever). The bio block was blank and sat above a dozen or so documents, most of which appeared to be articles or technical writings. I clicked on the "Bio" tab where only four of the fields were filled in- Type of Writer:technical, Favourite Movies: The Godfather, X-Men, The Imitation Game, Gender:Male, Location:England, South Coast.

I blinked. England, South Coast? Coincidence. That was where I lived.

Tabbing back to the review which still remained open in my inbox, I started to type a reply....
12.title: It's a constructive review, giving several ...

choices: It was the elderly gentlemen from the house next door
The knocker held a printed manuscript in her hand
It was myself
124.content: I stare at the door oddly, who could be there at this hour. In my neighborhood, people don't usually just drop by, they call first. I was just about to email Darkmouse9, I really didn't want leave it until later. I ignore the knock and begin to type an introduction, being mindful of my grammar and punctuation. They knock again, more persistently. I continue to ignore it, now out of principle; after all they are rudely pounding on my door. As the pounding comes again I got up, angry and prepared to counter rude with rude although I usually try to mediate rather than argue. I glance at my computer screen, tempted to turn around and let the angry knocker knock until they wearied themselves of it. I choose instead to find out who is there and why, bothered by their bad manners. It never occurs to me to be weary of them or why they were knocking. I drew a deep breath and turned the knob, swinging open the door I saw a familiar but unexpected face.
124.title: You suddenly hear a loud knock at your door

choices: The two meet at Stephan's to discuss story mistakes
The two decide to discuss the review on the phone
you decide which way to go
13.content:
"Oh my goodness my first review of this story.
I can't read it fast enough. Oh but it's only a few sentences long."

She reads the review as written and it says as follows:

Hi, I'm with the Power Reviewers group and I wanted to pop in and give you a quick run down of your story. I saw one or two type O's, they were for the most part insignificant, also you need to check your punctuation. There are a few other ways of improving your story if you would like further comment or help just email me and I'll be glad to go through it in more depth. thanks for sharing. God Bless you!

Well. I say to myself, what a short review, I am curious about what she found wrong with my story. and what other mistakes I might have made. looks like she would have told me in this email. I'm gonna email her and inquire about what she found wrong with my work.

EMAIL TO REVIEWER

Hello I just read your review of my story I must say it was very short and failed to aid me in correcting whatever is wrong with my story, if anything. I thought I would take you up on the offer to help me with my writing and correcting my errors. I realize I have a little bit of a problem when it comes to punctuation so I would appreciate you showing me where I messed up.

Sincerely


Email from Reviewer

I'd be happy to aid you. Why don't we meet for coffee at the local coffee shop "Stephan's" in the village.

Sincerely
13.title: It's a very short review, with an offer to ...

choices: Part 2 of Haunted Harriet's review
Let's take a snack break
14.content:
You read the first part of the review...

I was so surprised when I read your story. It could have been me that wrote it. The exact same thing happened to me!

Okay, maybe not the EXACT same thing, but something very similar.

I, too, was once challenged to do something which I thought I could not do. In my case it was spend the night in a haunted house, which I admit is not at all identical to the challenge in your story, but it is similar, right?

All my life I have been afraid of supernatural beings ever since a disastrous Halloween night when I was 9 years old and suffered a severe fright. That was the last Halloween I went out trick or treating. After that night I would just say, "I am too old for such childish activities," but really I was frightened to be outside on a Halloween night.

I was in my early 20's when I received my challenge and feeling unusually bold for a change. Normally, I was shy and skittish. But for some reason that night I accepted the challenge to spend the night in our local Haunted House.

A soon as I entered the house I knew I had made a mistake, but I didn't want to lose face by running right back out like a scared cat. I decided that I would wait a little while and perhaps be able to sneak out later.

Somehow I managed to fall asleep sitting there on the floor with my head nodded over. When I woke up with a start, I didn't know what time it was. I had a memory of some strange sound waking me up. I jumped to my feet and ran outside.

My friends were all standing there laughing. It had only been an hour. I must have been really tired to fall asleep like that. Or... something made me fall asleep?

Anyway, I was delighted and surprised to read your story. I did find a few errors of spelling and grammar which I shall discuss now...

You stop reading for a moment and ponder the reviewer's story. Odd that she would go on so in a review. Was she padding it for some reason?

Your stomach growls a little, but you want to finish reading the review. What do you do?
14.title: That happened to me!

choices: Thank the reviewer for his brutal honesty
Write an equally scathing reply to this reviewer
Proceed to google and cyber-stalk this reviewer
15.content:
Your eyes eagerly devour the precious feedback from your very first reviewer. You're so sure he'll agree that it's an amazing story. Who knows? He could even be an agent looking to promote budding authors!

However, your spirit dampens as you begin to read. By the time you get to the last word of his long, scathing review, you're ready to curl up into a ball and die.

You try to shake yourself out of it but the reviewer's negative comments keep swirling in your head.

The plot was predictable, the characters weak, and the climax non-existent. I truly wish I had something more encouraging to say but as it is, your story is really quite boring.

Another tear slides down your cheek.

It would be remiss of me to encourage you to continue writing in earnest. Your work is so inferior, you'll never stand a chance of getting published.

Your heart cracks just a little more as you recall that one.

I'm giving you one out of five stars -- and that's only because the system doesn't allow me to give a half-star rating. Sorry, but it's the truth, and I think you should know it."

You self-esteem goes down yet another notch.

I'll say this though: for someone whose first language isn't English, this is a brave attempt.

Not only are you a native English speaker, you are English!
15.title: the reviewer dislikes your story for many reasons

choices: You send as is and send to some one else
You delete a part of it to keep it positive,
You reread the story objectively to see if any of the comment could be true
151.content:
You begin to write your note as your thoughts are that everyone is entitled to an opinion and why should you allow one reviewer to disempower you.

Dear Reviewer:
Wow! Thank you so much for your thorough commentary of my work. I appreciate the time you have taken to review with such sincerity. Your point of view is interesting.

To be honest in return, I am English but will take your comments under advisement if they make any sense to me and my muse. I would have liked more specific pointers as opposed to general statements, but perhaps you have no the knowledge or advice that could help.

Thanks again for your time and consideration.

sincerely,


You stop and wonder if the line about the reviewer is a bit mean...as you really want to be honest yet above the negative vibes that can occur... You could just leave it with the wanting specific comments and dump the veiled insult---though it could be a truth as the reviewer could not really know how to help...
so..
151.title: Thank the reviewer for his brutal honesty

choices: The reviewer replies and offers help.
You never get a reply from the harsh reviewer.
While waiting for a reply, you get a constructive review
1513.content:
As you are rereading the story, you see several things you hadn't noticed when writing it. Things that could be better, you notice your grammar is not all it could be, after all, how long has it been since you really thought about punctuation and sentence structure? You see that your characters are kind of shallow and you realize that story wasn't really as great as you thought it was. The reviewer did have some valid points, although they did go a bit too far in some of their comments.

You delete your previous message and start over.

Dear Reviewer,

Thank you for taking the time to read and review my story. I appreciate the brutally honest feedback and see that you made some valid points. Do you have any tips or suggestion on how I could make this better? I am just starting out with writing stories and would love some advice. I may not be ready for publication yet, but that is why I joined this site, to improve my writing skills and to learn and everyone has to start somewhere.

You send it off and while waiting for a reply, begin to rewrite your story.
1513.title: You reread the story objectively to see if any ...

choices: Thank your lucky stars and reply enthusiastically.
Express your gratitude but decline firmly.
Confront the reviewer and demand an explanation.
15131.content:
To your surprise, the reviewer replies promptly. And in a conciliatory tone too! You're glad that you didn't respond rudely to his harsh review -- perhaps he was just having a bad day! The reviewer even offers to give you a line-by-line edit of your story.

You're grateful for the offer but also quite taken aback. Is this the same guy who sent you that scathing review five days ago? You can hardly believe the 180 degree change in attitude! He isn't just friendly, he is almost . . . too sweet . . .

Just as you are about to dismiss the thought, you come to the following lines:

" . . . but I can only do this for you if you agree to join me for dinner at the Ritz. I'll pay for any expenses incurred, of course. Please excuse my unusual request. You see, as the Editor-in-Chief of Kiss My Ass, I'm a very busy man, and can only make myself available to you over dinner . . . "

Your face darkens in consternation as you consider how to respond to this unexpected offer. Is it too good to be true?
15131.title: The reviewer replies and offers help.

choices: I go to the blunt reviewer"s port
I ask an experienced reviewer for feedback on my changes.
I curl up and read a book in my genre
15132.content:
I get to work on making some changes to my story while I wait for any responses from the blunt reviewer. I think how interesting it is that even though my initial reaction--was just that, a personal reaction--- it did make me sit up and activate my own critic in a positive way. If I take what comes to me as a bit of a reflection of myself--- then perhaps my fear of it being so bad merited my receiving such a tirade. Or maybe my own critic hiding inside really was negative and thought it was worse than it is. awareness can come in so many guises so I can find the balance and the Interesting POV instead of the the Right and Wrong ness of something.

I never did hear back from this reviewer so I guess his job was done. He either did not have pointers, was having a bad day and didn;t want to open the door again or just does his thing and moves on. Not worth pondering over.
I may go look in his port and see his work. Or not!

It woke me up to me and something to ponder.
15132.title: You never get a reply from the harsh reviewer.

choices: Let it go, and move on.
Block the reviewer
Rage, rage against the dying of the light.
151321.content:
and try to understand who this person is. For example, one reviewer gave me a one star on a story I wrote that won a site-wide story contest and, from the reviews prior to that, was pretty darn good and well received . His comment was that he didn't understand it. After looking at this bio (which was blank) and reading a few of his works, it was obvious that English wasn't his native language so I could understand his confusion. What I didn't understand was why he bothered to rate it at all.

I politely responded, asking what he didn't understand. Of course, I never heard back. I then sent a second response and suggested if he didn't understand something, perhaps he should have passed it and not commented. Again, I never heard back. The last time I checked, he was no longer on the site.

I would have loved to have had a conversation with him. Not everything I write is for all readers. Unfortunately, in this situation, I foresaw:

"So, you didn't understand what the story was about? "

"Story. Dead man. Speaks. No."

"Uhhh. What does that mean?"

"Story. Dead man. Speaks. No."

"You didn't understand about a dead man speaking? Well, he was brought back to life to right the wrongs of his life. He wasn't really dead. He was given a second chance."

"Story. Dead man. Speaks. No."

"Ohhh. OK. Well, I'm glad we had this chance to talk. By the way, I'm giving you one star for this conversation .

I agree, negative comments aren't pleasant but they do help us as writers to see through the reader's eyes. I read each one with care and use it to improve my clarity when writing ... except when it's obvious that the negative comments really weren't about the craft of writing or the story line.

As you so delicately put it, sometimes folks are just having a bad day and if they vent on one of my tales, then I guess in some twisted way, I've performed a service.

Still, you have to make a decision:
151321.title: I go to the blunt reviewer"s port

1513211.content:
After journaling about my experience for a few days, I conclude that it was real silly of me to waste time brooding over one person's opinion. After all, if even Stephen King can't make every reader a fan, who am I to think I can wow everybody?

I write down all the valid points from the review in my notebook, then delete it permanently from my inbox. I only need the pointers, not the negativity. A heavy load lifted off my chest as I clicked the "delete" button, confirming that I must have done the right thing. Good riddance to bad rubbish!

Then I open up a blank document on my computer and start typing out a new story . . . one that's about reviewers . . . Yup, this is definitely more productive!
1513211.title: Let it go, and move on.

choices: The 2nd Reviewer gives me a glowing review!
The 2nd Reviewer gives me the same feedback as the first!
The 2nd Reviewer ignores my request, and I don't hear from them.
151322.content:
After a few days, I decide to ask an experienced writer on the site to review my story. I'm terribly nervous about setting myself up for more criticism but I know that I cannot possibly improve if I do not allow my work to be critiqued.

I've worked long and hard at revising this story -- it's time I "put it to the test", so to speak. I look through the list of reviewers listed and choose one who seems the least intimidating. I'm sure there are some nice people out there!

So I put in my request and keep my fingers crossed. Who knows what this reviewer might say?
151322.title: I ask an experienced reviewer for feedback on m...

info.brief_description: When an author meets someone who sent her / him a review, face to face. HAPPY 10 POWER!
info.description:
This story was created to celebrate the 10th Anniversary of "WdC SuperPower Reviewers Group" !

GUIDELINES
FOR THOSE WHO ARE ADDING CHAPTERS:

Please make reasonable additions.

The story should go toward exchanging mails, planning a face-to-face meeting between the reviewer and the reviewed, and the actual meeting and how it goes, and maybe what happens after. Please think up interesting scenarios for this! You can take your time to get to the actual meeting. The first chapter, that I've done, is only about writing up the story and noticing that there is a review.

Please don't end the story too quickly. Please give fellow writers options to continue the story.

Keep all additions within the ASR rating, please.
Any chapters not following this rule will be deleted, and will not be considered for any rewards.

That's it for now. More guidelines will be added if needed!
